raw_text:
Rel: May 2, 2025
Notice: This unpublished memorandum is being issued to the
parties and to the trial-court judge. The memorandum is not
subject to publication and shall not be made a part of the public
court record by the trial-court clerk. This unpublished
memorandum should not be cited as precedent. See Rule 54, Ala.
R. App. P. Rule 54(d) states, in part, that this memorandum "shall
have no precedential value and shall not be cited in arguments
or briefs and shall not be used by any court within this state,
except for the purpose of establishing the application of the
doctrine of law of the case, res judicata, collateral estoppel,
double jeopardy, or procedural bar." Notwithstanding the
foregoing, a party may quote or cite this unpublished
memorandum in an application for rehearing or a petition for a
writ of certiorari arising from this decision.
ALABAMA COURT OF CIVIL APPEALS
OCTOBER TERM, 2024-2025
_________________________
CL-2024-0597
_________________________
Brittany Michelle Gilliland
v.
Christopher Blaine McGregor
Appeal from Tallapoosa Circuit Court
(DR-23-900051)
MEMORANDUM DECISION
CL-2024-0597
FRIDY, Judge.
Brittany Michelle Gilliland ("the wife") appeals from a judgment of
the Tallapoosa Circuit Court ("the trial court") divorcing her from
Christopher Blaine McGregor ("the husband"). We affirm the trial court's
judgment by unpublished memorandum.
Background
The husband and the wife married in 2018. (R.7.) They have two
children. (Id.) On August 18, 2023, the husband filed a complaint seeking
a divorce from the wife, alleging an irretrievable breakdown of the
marriage and requesting, among other things, an equitable division of
the marital estate, sole custody of the children, and possession of the
marital residence. (C.12–13.) That same day, the husband filed an ex
parte motion in which he alleged that the wife had bruised one of the
children by striking or grabbing her, and he sought a pendente lite award
of custody of the children, possession of the marital residence, and child
support. (C.15–16.) The trial court entered an order awarding the
husband custody of the children and possession of the marital residence
pendente lite and setting the matter for a hearing on September 12, 2023.
(C.17.)
2
CL-2024-0597
On September 8, 2023, the wife filed an answer generally denying
all material allegations in the husband's complaint; she also asserted a
counterclaim for a divorce. (C.19–21.) She alleged that the husband was
physically and mentally abusive, and she requested custody of the
children, spousal support, an equitable division of the marital estate and
marital debts, and possession of the marital residence. That same day,
the wife filed a motion to vacate the August 18, 2023, order, asserting
that the husband was alienating the children, that the allegation of abuse
in the husband's ex parte motion was false, and that the husband had
committed multiple acts of domestic violence, including an incident in
May 2023 in which he struck her on the head with a laptop computer.
(C.23–26.) The trial court set a hearing on the wife's motion for
September 12, 2023, at the same time on which it had set the hearing on
the husband's ex parte motion. (C.34.)
On September 12, 2023, the trial court held the scheduled hearing
on the parties' motions, at which it received ore tenus testimony. (C.47.)
The record reflects that one of the children testified at the hearing (R.13);
however, no transcript of that hearing is included in the record on appeal.
After the hearing, the trial court entered a pendente lite order in which,
3
CL-2024-0597
among other things, it awarded the parties joint legal custody of the
children, awarded the husband sole physical custody of the children and
use of the marital residence, and awarded the wife visitation with the
children. (C.47.)
The trial court held a trial in the case on November 6, 2023. (R.1.)
During the trial, the following exchange occurred:
"[The husband's attorney]: And, Judge, a lot of these
things are what we've introduced before. I don't know if the
Court wants to take judicial notice of what you got before, but
I'll be glad to go into them again.
"THE COURT: That's fine.
"[The wife's attorney]: Judge, I have no objection to you
adopting the full-fledged pendente lite hearing and
considering it as part of this.
"The [trial court]: All right. Let's do that.
"[The husband's attorney]: That's fine with me, Judge.
Thank you."
(R.19.) (Emphasis added.)
On February 1, 2024, the trial court entered a judgment, which it
vacated later that same day, stating that it had entered the judgment in
error. (C.83–91.) On February 27, 2024, the trial court entered a new
judgment. (C.92–99.) In it, the trial court, among other things, awarded
4
CL-2024-0597
the parties joint legal custody of the children, awarded the husband sole
physical custody of the children and possession of the marital residence,
and awarded the wife visitation with the children.
On March 20, 2024, the wife filed a motion to alter, amend, or
vacate the judgment (C.100–02), which was denied by operation of law,
see Rule 59.1, Ala. R. Civ. P. The wife filed a timely notice of appeal.
Analysis
In her brief to this court, the wife asserts that the evidence does not
support the trial court's award to the husband of sole physical custody of
the children. In his brief in response, the husband argues, among other
things, that the wife's failure to include in the record on appeal the
transcript from the pendente lite hearing requires affirmance of the trial
court's judgment.
On January 18, 2025 -- more than three months after the trial-court
clerk had certified the record on appeal and nearly two months after the
wife had filed her brief -- the wife filed in the trial court a motion
pursuant to Rule 10, Ala. R. App. P., seeking to supplement or correct the
record. In that motion, she asserted that the trial court had conducted
the pendente lite hearing, that a court reporter was present at that
5
CL-2024-0597
hearing, and that the court reporter transcribed the parties' testimony at
that hearing. On February 1, 2025, the wife filed in this court a motion
pursuant to Rule 10(f), Ala. R. App. P., in which she asserted that the
trial court had not corrected the record within fourteen days of the filing
of her motion, that she had requested that the transcript of the pendente
lite hearing be made a part of the appellate record, and that a court
reporter had been present. Notably, she wrote: "Counsel for [the wife] did
not notice the absence of the transcript from the record on appeal until it
was pointed out in [the husband's] Brief."
On February 3, 2025, the husband filed a response to the wife's Rule
10(f) motion, arguing that the absence of the transcript of the pendente
lite hearing had been apparent since the record was certified as complete,
that the transcript of the final hearing referenced the pendente lite
hearing being considered by the trial court in making its decision, and
that granting the wife relief pursuant to Rule 10(f) would be "patently
unfair" because it would deprive him of the opportunity to respond to the
additional testimony. The husband cited Bynum v. Bynum, 296 So. 2d
711, 725 (Ala. Civ. App. 1974), for the proposition that a judgment cannot
be reversed for insufficiency of the evidence when the supporting
6
CL-2024-0597
evidence is not contained in the record on appeal. On February 18, 2025,
this court denied the wife's request to supplement the record on appeal
pursuant to Rule 10(f).
Both of the issues the wife raises on appeal rest on the sufficiency
of the evidence supporting the trial court's judgment. However, the
record reflects that the trial court had before it both the evidence received
at the final hearing as well as the evidence presented at the pendente lite
hearing. Although the transcript of the final hearing is included in the
record on appeal, the transcript of the pendente lite hearing is not.
Rule 10(b), Ala. R. App. P., required the wife to include in the record
on appeal "all evidence relevant" to any finding or conclusion she
intended to challenge on appeal. If the transcript was omitted despite
being designated, Rule 10(f) required her to move the trial court to
supplement or to correct the record and to attach a copy of the transcript-
purchase order as proof that the omitted portion of the transcript was
originally requested.
In her Rule 10(f) motion, the wife acknowledged that the transcript
from the pendente lite hearing was necessary for meaningful appellate
review and stated that she had not realized that the transcript was
7
CL-2024-0597
missing until the husband raised the issue in his appellee's brief.
Notably, in her brief to this court, she asserts that "the totality of the
evidence presented" failed to support the trial court's custody
determination. However, in her Rule 10(f) filing, she described the
transcript of the pendente lite hearing as containing evidence supporting
the "crucial issue" for appeal, despite its omission from the record on
appeal. It is well settled that the appellant bears the burden of ensuring
that the record on appeal contains sufficient evidence to warrant reversal
of the judgment at issue and of confirming the accuracy of the appellate
record. See Goree v. Shirley, 765 So. 2d 661, 662 (Ala. Civ. App. 2000).
When oral testimony is presented and a transcript of that testimony or a
Rule 10(d) statement of the evidence is not included in the record on
appeal, this court must conclusively presume that the omitted testimony
supports the trial court's judgment. See Quick v. Burton, 960 So. 2d 678,
680 (Ala. Civ. App. 2006).
At trial, the wife's counsel expressly stated that he did not object to
the trial court considering the evidence presented at the pendente lite
hearing as part of the trial. The transcript of the final hearing further
reflects that the trial court agreed to consider that testimony in rendering
8
CL-2024-0597
its judgment. Because that testimony is not included in the appellate
record -- either as a transcript or as a Rule 10(d) statement of the
evidence -- we must conclusively presume that that testimony supports
the trial court's judgment. See Quick, 960 So. 2d at 680. Accordingly, the
wife has not demonstrated reversible error.
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, the trial court's judgment is affirmed.
AFFIRMED BY UNPUBLISHED MEMORANDUM.
Moore, P.J., and Edwards, Hanson, and Lewis, JJ., concur.
9
